In Aramaic – קרטיגניא or קרתיגניא or דמן קרטגנין or other such variations.
Appears in rabbinic literature, see Introduction 6.7, and bears the title “rabbi”, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.4.

Since in the parallel tradition he is designated Isaac, and since “abba” is also a title, see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.1, p. 33, perhaps this sage was called אבא יצחק דמן קרטגנין (Abba Isaac of Carthage).

The inscription was considered Jewish because of the combination “̓Ωνείας ἀρχιερεύς” (Onias, high-priest) perhaps referring to a number of Jewish high-priests from the 2nd century BCE (Honi [1-4] [S-H/M] in vol. 1, p. 177), but is rejected by CIJ on the grounds that neither is uniquely Jewish, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.3, but also above, n. 1. The inscription includes the pagan formula Θ(εοῖς) Κ(αταχθονίοις) (to the gods of the underworld), see Introduction 6.10.2.1.

This Greek amulet, found in Britain, is an enigma. It is particularly Jewish in character, including expressions such as ̓Αδωναῖε ̓Ελωαῖε Σαβαωθ (אדוני אלהי צבאות); ελλιων ἁνωρα (עליון הנורא); βαρουχ αθθα ουβαρου <χ> ο̓δηχα ἀ <δ>εὶ ωλαμ λεωλαμ (ברוך אתה וברוך עודך עדי עולם לעולם), and quotes Exodus 3:14 (ειε εσαρ ειε – אהיה אשר אהיה), see Introduction 6.9.1. It is probably the most Jewish of all amulets in Kotansky’s collection. Yet it was found in Wales, the further most point in the Roman Empire from Palestine. It may have been brought by a Roman soldier, but was he Jewish? Kotansky thinks ̓Αλφινόν is the Latin cognomen Alfaeus, but see inRNGCL 11 where under this name we are referred to the Greek spelling “Alphaius,” indicating the non-Roman origins of this name. I assume it may be the Aramaic חליפא/חלפי, and that the man was a Jewish soldier from the Eastern provinces of the Roman Empire. Kotansky also makes much of the mention of the Egyptian god Θουθ in the text. Thus, I consider his Jewishness likely but not decisive.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.

The story is found in an appendix to a Jewish-Christian controversy of 632 CE, but may have happened sometime later, since the disputants are a Jew and a Muslim. Also the father’s name is Arabic.
The manuscript mentions no provenance, I assume it refers to Egypt, because such disputes between Jews and persons of other religions were common there.

He is described as contesting with an emperor. In view of the date of this tradition we may assume he was the Roman Emperor in Rome.

See above, n. 11.
The inscription is dated.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The editor was not certain whether it should be read with the letter ד or ר.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. However, this is a list of names, none of them strictly Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
On such transliterations see Introduction 2.7.
Described in the papyrus together with the other witnesses as ̓Ιουδαῖοι τῆς ἐπιγονῆς (Jews of the epigone), see Introduction 6.1.1.2.
The papyrus is dated.
So in some mss, see I. Thurn, Ioannis Malalae Chronographia (Berlin 2000) 348. This name is recorded in NT. For this name in Jewish characters see under Toma (1) (S-H/M) in vol. 1 p. 416.
In Greek – σιλεντιάριος.
In some mss he is described as ̔ λεγόμενος ̔Εβραῖος (who is called [the] Hebrew), see Malalas, Chronographia, 348, and Introduction 6.1.2.
His appointment is derived from the emperor in Constaninople, in Asia. It is assumed that he resided there as well.
He is associated with the great earthquake in Antioch, which took place in this year.
My reading.
The papyrus is composed in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.4.
The papyrus is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

state.note: Dedicatory inscription on church chancel screen, Kayikçili

person.note: On such transliterations see Introduction 2.7.
In Greek – προτοπ[ρ]εσβύτερος
Jewishness suggested based on name, see above, n. 1. Although this is clearly a Jewish name, this inscription was found inscribed on a church chancel screen.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. However, this is a list of names, none of them strictly Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
On such transliterations see Introduction 2.7.
In Greek – ὡς ἐτῶν γ’.
On inscriptions from Leontopolis see Introduction 6.5.1.

div.note: אבא means “father” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 2. For the Aramaic name see Lipiński, Studies1, 190-4. אבא is documented as a name on a First Temple Hebrew seal, see CWSSS, no. 44; in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 1; and for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 8. Further on this name see vol. 1, p. 358.
אב means “father” in Hebrew, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 2. This name is derived from it. The form ’BH is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 16. And see also vol. 2 (S-H/M).

אב means “father” in Hebrew, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 2. This name is derived from it. The name אבינה is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 12. The forms ’BN’ and ’BYN’ are recorded names for Palmyrans, see Stark, PNPI, 1-2. For this name in Jewish characters see vol. 2 (S-H/M).

אב means “father” in Hebrew, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 2. This name is derived from it. The name אביתע is recorded for Idumeans, see AOFCI34. The form אביתי is unknown from elsewhere but is recorded 7 times on Aramaic papyri from Hellenistic Egypt, 5 of which answer strict criteria for Jewishness. In addition, the name is recorded in Greek (̓Αβιῆτος) in another 11 documents, of which 2 are Jews according to strict criteria. All the others were identified as Jewish based on name, but this is a circular argument, see Introduction 6.6.2.

אדי means “to swing, throw, pitch” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 16. See also Lipiński, Studies 1, 101-2. It is recorded on an Aramaic, Persian-period seal, see CWSSS, no. 759, and in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 65. See for this name in Jewish characters also under אדי in vol. 1, p. 360.

This looks like a biblical name, see Noth, IPRGN, 101-14, and on its Jewish character see especially pp. 111-2. The name אסף is biblical, see e.g. 2 Kgs 18:18. However, this form is not recorded in the Bible, or elsewhere, for Jews. According to CWSSS, no. 253 (למשלם אסף), editors first read the second name as אספי.
אספליאה means “solemn declaration” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 95. The form ’SFL is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 44.

בוכריא means “baccar, an aromatic plant supposed to be hazelwortor spike-nard” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 145. בוכרא means “first-born” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 145. בכרי is recorded as a name in the Bible (e.g. 2 Sam 20:1). Noth, IPRGN, 230, interprets it as deriving from בכר – young camel. Negev, Qedem32, no. 180, records the name בכרו for Nabateans. The form BKRW is a recorded name in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 9, and BKR is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 114. According to WGE, 218, Βόκχορις is a Greek form of an Egyptian king’s name. In Persian the names Βόχρης and Buχārā are recorded, see Justi, INB, 70-1. For this name in Jewish characters see vol. 1, pp. 362-3.
בזכא means “vessel” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 153.
בחי means “to look out, be cautious” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 155. The form BḤYN is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 96.

בידא means “fiction, false” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 159. The form BDYH is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 98. The forms BYD’ and BYDN are recorded names for Palmyrans, see Stark, PNPI, 9. If this is understood a Hebrew name with the theophoric suffix יה, it is interesting to note the existence of the Hebrew name with the theophoric element אל in it – בידאל (Bidel), see Heltzer & Ohana, Extra-Biblical Tradition, 37.
גברא means “man” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 208. The form JBR is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 150, and GBR’ is a recorded name for Palmyrans, see Stark, PNPI, 13.

גדיא means “kid” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 211. However, this name is probably derived from the Aramaic god of fortune, גד, as is the biblical name of גד the son of Jacob (e.g. Gen 30:11), see Introduction 1.6.1. On this name in the talmudic period see E. Friedheim, “The Names ‘Gad’, ‘Gada’ and ‘Gadya’ among Palestinian and Babylonian Sages and the Rabbinic Struggle against Pagan Influences,” in A. Demsky (ed.) These are the Names: Studies in Jewish Onomastics3 (Ramat Gan 2002) 117-26 (Hebrew). Names deriving from it were popular, e.g. CWSSS, nos. 12, 467, and others in that collection; Heltzer & Ohana, Extra-Biblical Tradition, 38-9. גדיא is documented as a name for Nabataeans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 214, and for Palmyrans, see Stark, PNPI, 13. For this name in Jewish characters see vol. 1, pp. 366-7.

דלו means “irrigation” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 309. On this name from Palestine in the Persian period see Heltzer & Ohana, Extra-Biblical Tradition, 41. The form DLY is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 242.

דמא means “to be dumb” or “to suspect” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 313. In theBavli the name is assigned to a gentile – דמא בן נתינה from Ashkelon (e.g. in bAZ 23b). It is recorded as a name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 242. The form DMY (or RMY) is a recorded name for Palmyrans, see Stark, PNPI, 14. For this name in Jewish characters see vol. 1, pp. 372-3.

הון/הונא means “proper conduct” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 339. The name הנא is a recorded name for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 307. The form HN’ is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 625.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
I assume this is a nickname with a haprefix, see vol. 1, Appendix, pp. 445-8.
זעירא means “small, young, tender, lesser” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 407. זערן is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 298.

The root חבב means “to love” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 415-7. חבובא/חיבובא means “beloved, see ”Jastrow, ibid. 450. ḤBWB and ḤBYB are recorded names for Palmyrans, see Stark, PNPI, 19. ḤBB is a recorded name for Arabs, Harding, ICPIANI, 173.

Neither this name, nor any of its variants, are mentioned in the Hebrew Bible, but they clearly belong to the family of biblical names such as יוחנן and חנניה. This is particularly obvious with relation to Honi (1) (S-H/M) in vol. 1, p. 377, son of Simon (4) (B/M) in vol. 1, p. 218, the Just (שמעון הצדיק) who is designated ̓Ονίαςby Josephus (AJ 12:44) and חוניו in the Bavli (bMen 109b), but יוחנן in Sirach and נחוניון in the Yerushalmi (yYoma 6:3, 43d). Thus, the names are clearly of the same family and interchangeable. One may assume that חוני / חניה / חוניו are Aramicized, as befits the post-biblical period. It appears that in post-biblical times this name became identified as uniquely Jewish, and was, as a rule, not used by non-Jews. Thus, it is a rare case where a non-biblical name is considered uniquely Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.2.
חייא means “life” or “midwife” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 454. ḤYW is recorded as a name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 211; חיא is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 429.

חליפה means “replacement, substitution” in Hebrew, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 469. חלפן and חלפת are recorded names for Idumeans, see AOFCI, 99. ḤLYP’, ḤLYPY and ḤLPW are recorded names in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 22-3. ḤLF is recorded as a name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 227. The Nabateans used חליפו, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 448. For this name in Jewish characters see vol. 1, p. 381.
This could be the abbreviated Hebrew theophoric name ידליהו, see CWSSS, no. 161.
כהנא means “priest” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 615. And see also vol. 2 (S-H/M).

מאור means “luminary, light” in Hebrew, but at the same time מאירא/מאירתא means “curse, evil etc.,” see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 721-4. מאר is recorded as a name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 523. Although the name has a clear Hebrew meaning, it is not biblical. The rabbis explain it thus in bEruv 13b: תנא: לא רבי מאיר שמו אלא רבי נהוראי שמו, ולמה נקרא שמו רבי מאיר? שהוא מאיר עיני חכמים בהלכה (His name is not Rabbi Meir, but Rabbi Nehorai. And why is he called Rabbi Meir? Because he lights up the eyes of the sages in the law, Cohen, JJS 23 (1972), argued that the name is Anatolian. The finds in this corpus confirm her conclusion. Of the four Meirs recorded here, one is in Hebrew and late, and the other three are Anatolian, and see also Introduction 6.6.2, and Zgusta, Anatolische Personennamensippen, 79, 143.

מלכא in Aramaic means “king,” see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 791. This name is not biblical, but the form מלכיה is recorded in the Bible, see 1 Chr 9:12. MLK’ and MLKW are recorded names in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 32-4; MLK and many of its derivatives are recorded as names for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 564-6, and for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem32, nos. 642, 644-7. See also Introduction 6.6.2. For this name in Hebrew charaters see vol. 1, pp. 390-1.
מקימה means “bought object, thing” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 831. This is a Palmyran name, see Stark, PNPI, 35-7.

מרא means “lord, master” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 834. The name is recorded on an Aramaic First Temple seal, see CWSSS, no. 808; in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 37; for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 542; and for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 691.

The name is theophoric, and Canaanite, with the name of the Canaanite goddess, עשתרת (Astarte) inserted, see Introduction 1.6.1. It is modeled on names such as the Hebrew מתניה (see e.g. 2 Kgs 24:17).

נדב is a biblical name (e.g. 1 Kgs 11:20), as is נדביה (1 Chr 3:18). On the non-biblical, Aramaic suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.1, p. 23. The form NDB’L is recorded in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 39.
נוכרי/נוכרא means “strange, stranger, gentile” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 887. The form NKR is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 598.
נחתומא means “baker” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 897.

נפל in Aramaic means “to fall, lie down, be dropped,” see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 924. The form NFL is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 597. נפילו and נפלי are recorded names for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, nos. 743-4.

סבא means “gray, old, elder, grandfather” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 948. In the Bible (e.g. 1 Chr 1:9) this is the name of an African nation. Only in post-biblical times did it become a suitable name for Jews. It is also recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 308, and in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 40. For this name in Jewish characters see also vol. 1, pp. 395-6.
סלף means “to twist, pervert” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 996. The form SLFN is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 325.

סמא means “drug, medicine, poison, paint” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 998. סומא means “blind” in Aramaic see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 966. The form SM is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 326. The form SMY’ is a recorded name for Palmyrans, see Stark, PNPI, 41.

The term ערביע refers to Arabia, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1113. ‘RBY is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 414, and for Palmyrans, see Stark, PNPI, 45. The name ערביו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 939.

ערובא is the Aramaic for the Hebrew biblical ערוב (one of the plagues of Egypt), see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1114. ערבא means “bondsman, surety” as in bBB173b. Alternatively, the name could derive from ערבי-Arab, see previous name.
צלח means “succeed, prosper” in Hebrew and “to split, pass through” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1283. The form SḶH is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 374.
צפעון means “adder” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1297.
קטיעא means “mutilated” or “dwarfed” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1348. The form Q̣T‘N is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 467.

This could be the Hebrew רחבאל, similar to the biblical name רחבעם (e.g. 1 Kgs 11:43), but as a name is not recorded anywhere. The form RHB’L is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 272. Or, it could include the Babylonian theophoric element Bel, see Introduction 1.6.1.

This name could be understood as theophoric in the context of biblical names such as עמרם (Ex 6:18), or רחבעם (1 Kgs 11:43) and see Noth, IPRGN, 76-82, but it is not recorded in the Bible. The form ŠB‘M is, however, a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 338.

שיב means “seven” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1556. שיבו is a recorded name for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1121; ŠYB is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 363; and ŠYBY is recorded for Palmyrans, see Stark, PNPI, 51.

שלי / שלא in Aramaic means “to be at ease, quite, unconcerned,” see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1582. This name is already documented on Hebrew seals from the First Temple period, see CWSSS, no. 280, and perhaps also no. 588. The form שלא is a recorded name for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1153. ŠL’ (feminine) is a recorded name for Palmyrans, see Stark, PNPI, 51. For this name in Jewish characters see vol. 1, pp. 414-5.

שמתי means “one who is under a ban” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1593. The name שמתו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1164. The form ŠMT is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 356.

This name could be understood as theophoric in the context of biblical names such as עמרם (Ex 6:18), and see Noth, IPRGN, 76-82, but it is not recorded in the Bible. The form ŠR‘M is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 347.

שרת in Hebrew means “to serve, minister, attend,” see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1635. שרתי is documented on Hebrew seals from the First Temple period, see CWSSS, no. 280, and perhaps also no. 588. שרתו is documented for Idumeans, see AOFCI, 100, and ŠRT is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 344.
תבא means “put into, fit, combine” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1642. The form TB’ is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 127.

תומא means “simplicity” or “garlic” or “fringe” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1654. In Hebrew, תאום means “twin,” see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1642. In the New Testament, the name Thomas is translated into Greek as Δίδυμος, i.e. “twin.” T’M is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 127. Also, the Nabatean name תאומא is recorded, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1193.

תנחומין means “consolation” in Hebrew, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1681. The name תנחם is documented in Hebrew and Ammonite First Temple seals, see CWSSS, nos. 707-8, 947, and on other First Temple documents, see Heltzer & Ohana, Extra-Biblical Tradition, 71. Although it is not biblical, the name has a clear Hebrew meaning and from rabbinic literature it is clear that the name was conceived as Jewish at this time (see under Tanhum S-H/M, vol. 2).
The form TSY is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 132.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
תתא means “below” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1705. The form TT is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 128.
